questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with the following findings as shown in the below image. Which of the following clinical tests will be helpful in identifying the affected muscle?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Park 3-step test In the given question, the patient is suffering from hypertropia in the right eye. The clinical test which can be used to identify the affected muscle is the park-3 step test.

Highyeild:

Park three-step test Step 1: Identify the hypertropic eye in the primary(straight-ahead) position. This implies that either one of the two depressors of the hypertropic eye or one of the two elevators of the hypertropic eye is weak. Step 2: Ask the patient to look horizontally right and then left and see in which position the deviation is more.Remembering that the deviation increases in the direction of action of the paralysed muscle, identify which two of the four muscles are likely to be affected. Step 3: Tilt the patient’s head towards each shoulder and see in which direction the vertical squint increases. Remembering that on tilting the head towards one shoulder, the eye on the same side intorts and the other eye extorts, the ipsilateral synergist of the paralysed muscle will try to intort or export the globe as the case may be, and since the muscle also has a vertical action, that vertical effect will be more prominent in the paralysed eye.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. The cover uncover test is used to identify latent squint or phoria and is not useful for identifying muscle affected. Option: B. Swinging flashlight test is done in case of RAPD

questions.text: A patient with hypertropia in the right eye presented to the ophthalmology clinic. On asking the patient to look to the left, the deviation increases. Also, on performing a head tilt to the right, the deviation increases. Which of the following muscles is affected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Right So In the given question, it is given that the patient is having hypertropia in the right eye. we can simply use the park 3-step test to identify the muscle involved. Park three-step test- Identify the hypertropic eye in the primary (straight-ahead) position. This implies that either one of the two depressors of the hypertropic eye or one of the two elevators of the hypotropic eye is weak. So in this case, right eye is hypertropic so either depressor of right eye (RSO or RIR) is affected or elevators of the left eye affected (LSR or LIO) Ask the patient to look horizontally right and then left and see in which position the deviation is more. Deviation increase in the direction of paralysed muscle. In this, as the patient look to the left, deviation increases so either RSO (acts in adducted position) or LSR is affected (acts in abducted position of the eye.) Step 3. Tilt the patient's head towards each shoulder and see in which direction the vertical squint increases Remembering that on tilting the head towards one shoulder, the eye on the same side intorts and the other eye extorts. The deviation increase in the direction of the paralysed muscle. Here, the deviation increases on tilting the head to the right. Hence the involved muscle will be right intorter which in this case will be right superior oblique.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Left IR - involved muscle will be right intorter which in this case will be right superior oblique. Option: C. Right IR - involved muscle will be right intorter which in this case will be right superior oblique. Option: D. Left SR. - involved muscle will be right intorter which in this case will be right superior oblique. Hence the correct answer will be option A.

questions.text: During the evaluation of hypertropia in a patient with the help of a park three-step test, the muscle involved was identified to be the left superior rectus. Which of the following statements regarding the findings in each step is not correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient will present with right hypertropia.

options.label: B
options.text: The deviation will increase on looking to the left.

options.label: C
options.text: The patient will present with left hypotropia.

options.label: D
options.text: On tilting the head to the right the deviation will increase.

questions.correct_answer: D. On tilting the head to the right the deviation will increase.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

On tilting the head to the right the deviation will increase. In the given question, the muscle which is affected is the left superior rectus. Hence the park three-step test finding will be- Step 1. In the primary position, the right eye will be hypertrophic or the left eye will be hypertrophic in case of involvement of the left superior rectus . (hence, Option A and Option C are correct) Step 2. On looking towards the left, the deviation will increase as it acts in an abducted eye. (option B is correct) Step 3. On tilting the head to the left, the deviation will increase, as the left eye will intort increasing the deviation in case of involvement of the left superior rectus. Hence option D is an incorrect statement.

Highyeild:

Park three-step test Step 1: Identify the hypertropic eye in the primary(straight-ahead) position. This implies that either one of the two depressors of the hypertropic eye or one of the two elevators of the hypertropic eye is weak. Step 2: Ask the patient to look horizontally right and then left and see in which position the deviation is more.Remembering that the deviation increases in the direction of action of the paralysed muscle, identify which two of the four muscles are likely to be affected. Step 3: Tilt the patient’s head towards each shoulder and see in which direction the vertical squint increases. Remembering that on tilting the head towards one shoulder, the eye on the same side intorts and the other eye extorts, the ipsilateral synergist of the paralysed muscle will try to intort or export the globe as the case may be, and since the muscle also has a vertical action, that vertical effect will be more prominent in the paralysed eye.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. The patient will present with right hypertropia. In the primary position, the right eye will be hypertrophic or the left eye will be hypertrophic in case of involvement of the left superior rectus Option: B. On looking towards the left, the deviation will increase as it acts in an abducted eye. Option: C. The patient will present with left hypotropia. In the primary position, the right eye will be hypertrophic or the left eye will be hypertrophic in case of involvement of the left superior rectus .

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presented with right eye hypertropia. On further evaluation, when asked to look to the right, the deviation increases in the left eye. When asked to tilt the head to the right, the deviation also increases. Which of the following muscles is affected?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

LIO In the given question, the patient presented with hypertropia in the right eye. So, applying the park three-step test- Right hypertropia means- either the right eye depressor (RSO or RIR) is affected or the left eye elevator (LSR or LIO) is affected. Step 2. On looking to the right, the deviation increases i.e. LIO (because it acts in the abducted eye) or RIR (as it will act in the abducted eye) is affected. Step3. On tilting the head to the right, the right eye will undergo intorsion and the left eye will undergo extortion. Hence, the affected muscle will be Left inferior oblique as the deviation increases on tilting the head to the right. So, the correct option is option C.

Highyeild:

Park three-step test Step 1: Identify the hypertropic eye in the primary(straight-ahead) position. This implies that either one of the two depressors of the hypertropic eye or one of the two elevators of the hypertropic eye is weak. Step 2: Ask the patient to look horizontally right and then left and see in which position the deviation is more.Remembering that the deviation increases in the direction of action of the paralysed muscle, identify which two of the four muscles are likely to be affected. Step 3: Tilt the patient’s head towards each shoulder and see in which direction the vertical squint increases. Remembering that on tilting the head towards one shoulder, the eye on the same side intorts and the other eye extorts, the ipsilateral synergist of the paralysed muscle will try to intort or export the globe as the case may be, and since the muscle also has a vertical action, that vertical effect will be more prominent in the paralysed eye.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. LIR - the affected muscle will be Left inferior oblique as the deviation increases on tilting the head to the right. Option: B . RSO - the affected muscle will be Left inferior oblique as the deviation increases on tilting the head to the right. Option: D. RSR - the affected muscle will be Left inferior oblique as the deviation increases on tilting the head to the right.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male who is a businessman by occupation presented to ophthalmologic OPD with concern regarding her look due to the following presentation as given in the image. The ophthalmologist performed park three tests on the patient. On looking to the right, the deviation increased. On tilting the head to the right, the deviation increased. Which of the following muscles is affected?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

RSR Step 1. – In th e primary position, the left eye is hypertropic . That means either the left eye depressor (LSO or LIR) is affected or the right eye elevator (RSR or RIO). On looking to the right, the deviation in the eye increases , so the affected muscle can be – RSR or LSO is affected. On tilting the head to the right , the right eye will undergo intorsion or the left eye undergoes extortion. As the deviation increases on tilting to the right the muscle affected will be RSR.

Highyeild:

Park three-step test Step 1: Identify the hypertropic eye in the primary(straight-ahead) position. This implies that either one of the two depressors of the hypertropic eye or one of the two elevators of the hypertropic eye is weak. Step 2: Ask the patient to look horizontally right and then left and see in which position the deviation is more.Remembering that the deviation increases in the direction of action of the paralysed muscle, identify which two of the four muscles are likely to be affected. Step 3: Tilt the patient’s head towards each shoulder and see in which direction the vertical squint increases. Remembering that on tilting the head towards one shoulder, the eye on the same side intorts and the other eye extorts, the ipsilateral synergist of the paralysed muscle will try to intort or export the globe as the case may be, and since the muscle also has a vertical action, that vertical effect will be more prominent in the paralysed eye.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. LIO - As the deviation increases on tilting to the right the muscle affected will be RSR. Option: C. RIR - not the correct option Option: D. LSO - not the correct option, in this case

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient was being evaluated for right hypertropia. On the evaluation of the person, the following finding was noted- 1. On looking towards the right side, the deviation increases. 2. On tilting the head to the left side, the deviation increases. Which of the following is the nerve supply of the affected muscle?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oculomotor Nerve In the given clinical scenario, the interpretation of the park three-step test can be done as The patient presented with right hypertropia- which means either the right depressor ( RIR or RSO) or left elevator (LIO or LSR) is affected. On looking towards the right, deviation increases so the muscles involved can be right inferior rectus or left inferior oblique. On tilting the head to the left, the deviation increases which means either the left intorters or right extorter is affected. Hence the answer came out to be the right inferior rectus. As asked in the question, about the nerve supply of the affected muscle, it will be the oculomotor/ 3rd cranial nerve. So the correct answer will be A.

Highyeild:

Park three-step test Step 1: Identify the hypertropic eye in the primary(straight-ahead) position. This implies that either one of the two depressors of the hypertropic eye or one of the two elevators of the hypertropic eye is weak. Step 2: Ask the patient to look horizontally right and then left and see in which position the deviation is more.Remembering that the deviation increases in the direction of action of the paralysed muscle, identify which two of the four muscles are likely to be affected. Step 3: Tilt the patient’s head towards each shoulder and see in which direction the vertical squint increases. Remembering that on tilting the head towards one shoulder, the eye on the same side intorts and the other eye extorts, the ipsilateral synergist of the paralysed muscle will try to intort or export the globe as the case may be, and since the muscle also has a vertical action, that vertical effect will be more prominent in the paralysed eye.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Trochlear nerve Option: C. Abducens nerve - supple lateral rectus as shown in above image. Option: D. Facial nerve

questions.text: A 31-year-old female presented with left hypotropia. When evaluated by the ophthalmologist, she was made to do the park three-step test which revealed the affected muscle to be right superior oblique. Which of the following will be the group of muscles that will be excluded after the second step of the park test is completed?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

RIR and LIO In the given question, the muscle affected after evaluation by the park three-step test comes out to be right superior oblique. We are asked about the muscles which can be excluded after completing step 2 of the park To approach such a question, we will start from the beginning, The position in the primary gaze is left hypotropia or right hypertropia. Hence the group of muscles that will be affected in this will be either the right depressor ( RSO or RIR ) or the left elevator (LIO or LSR ). In the 2nd step of the park test, we will ask the patient to look to the right or left side to see in which direction the deviation increases . In the given question, as the affected muscle is right superior oblique, hence we can make out in which direction the deviation will increase because of it. As the deviation increases in the direction of paralysed muscle, on looking left the deviation will increase in this patient. So the muscles now which can still be affected are RSO or LSR. So the two muscles excluded after step 2 will be RIR and LIO. Hence, the answer will be option A.

Highyeild:

Park three-step test Step 1: Identify the hypertropic eye in the primary(straight-ahead) position. This implies that either one of the two depressors of the hypertropic eye or one of the two elevators of the hypertropic eye is weak. Step 2: Ask the patient to look horizontally right and then left and see in which position the deviation is more.Remembering that the deviation increases in the direction of action of the paralysed muscle, identify which two of the four muscles are likely to be affected. Step 3: Tilt the patient’s head towards each shoulder and see in which direction the vertical squint increases. Remembering that on tilting the head towards one shoulder, the eye on the same side intorts and the other eye extorts, the ipsilateral synergist of the paralysed muscle will try to intort or export the globe as the case may be, and since the muscle also has a vertical action, that vertical effect will be more prominent in the paralysed eye.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. RSO and LSR - the muscles now which can still be affected are RSO or LSR. Option: C. RIR and RSO - the muscles now which can still be affected are RSO or LSR. Option: D . LSR and LIO - not the correct option.
